ATTEMPTED MURDER AT STAMFORD HILL.
On Saturday night an extraordinary and apparently
deliberate attempt to murder a woman, the wile of
a houze and estate agent named Tomlinzon, of Ts
Champion-terrace, Stamford Gill, took placein the
public thoroughfare, about one hundred yards dis-
tance from her residence, She left home at twenty
minutes past nine for the purpose of making 4 few
purchasea, and was almost immediated accosted by a
man from behind, She turned round at once, and
found that it was her siater’s husband, Willfam
Esworthy. He walked by her aide for a second or
two, and then suddenly fired o pistol at the back of
her head, Sheecreamed, ‘‘ Murder; Lam shot !” and
fell to the ground insensible, A’girl living on the spot
ran across the road and recognised Mrs, Tomlinson as
she lay bleeding on the pavement. Boing Saturday
night there were many people about. A crowd soon
aseembled, and the injured woman having been car-
ried into her own house, Dr, Duncan, of Amherst
Park, was sent for, He scon arrived, and found
her suffering from a bullet wound behind the right
ear, but the bullet had not penetrated the skull,
having bounded off after striking the bone, Search
waa subsequently made for the bullet, but it
could not be found. After the woman fell Esworthy
hurried to the opposite side of the street, and threw
something over a fence, He had been seen to fire
the pistol by some passers by, and was seized by
several men, who took him towarda the Stoke
Newington Police-station. They wore met, however,
by Sergeant Collina, of the N Division, to whom
they reported the circumatances of the case, and gave
the man into his custody. Collins, accompanied by
a great many persons, conveyed Hsworthy to the
Tottenham Police-station, Thera he waa charged
with “shooting and wounding with intent to murder
one Harriet Tomlinson, at the High-road, Stamford
Hill, in the parish of Tottenham.” He gave the name
of William Esworthy, aged twenty-eight, address 29,
South-street, Mancheater-aquare ; business, commis.
sion agent. On the charge being yead over to him
he remarked, ‘(She did it herself, and I took the
revolver away from her, and threw it over a fence
on the opposite side of the road,” On being searched
a few coing and a cleaning-rod of a pistol was found
upon him, but no ammunition, The prisoner having
been locked up, Inspector Ashwell and Sergeant
Colling proceeded to the spot indicated by him to
search for the revolver; but, after @ close inspec-
tion for an hour or 80, they had not succeeded in
finding it, The search then discontinued ; it was re-
sumed on Sunday morning at daylight by Sergeant
Collins, and at a quarter-past five o'clock he dis-
covered the revolver in a builder's yard, almost
opposite where the crime was committed, It is a
weapon with seven chambers, six of which were
loaded when it was picked up, Ib was, therefore,
fully charged when the attack waa made upon Mrs.
Tomlinson,

In investigating the matter on Sunday the polics
ascertained that the prisoner spent nearly the whole
of Saturday afternoon and evening watching the
playing of cricket on some vacant land at the rear of
Champion-terrace, After the match was over he was
geen to pass Tomlingon’s place of business and go to
a public-house, where he had some whisky, He then
repassed the shop, and evidently waited about in the
expectation that Mra, Tomlinson would come out,
ag she eventually did, to make Saturday night's
purchases, As to the motive for the outrage, it ig
stated that there had been serious disagreements
hetween the prisoner and his wife, and that Mra,
Torlinson had supported her eister’s cause, and
invited her to come to Stamford Hilland stay there on
several occasions, which she had done, Mrs. Tom-
lingon, ia the mother of two children, and is much
respected by her neighbours, who express great sym-
pathy towards her in her suffering, and make anxious
inquiries as to her condition, It ig clear that she
had @ miraculous escape from death, As it is she is
badly wounded, and her system has received a very
gevere shock, but there ia scarcely any fear of her
ultimate recovery. On Sunday evening the symp-
toms ware highly favourable to that view. As may
be imagined, the affair, happening in a crowded
thoroughfare at a busy time on Satarday night,
created intense excitement. Prisoner will be taken
before the magistrates ab Edmonton in a day or two.
